newsitem.title: BELGIUM: U.S. firm sees new hi-tech devices getting smaller.
newsitem.headline: U.S. firm sees new hi-tech devices getting smaller.

text.p: By Neil Winton, Science and Technology Correspondent
Miniaturisation is the key to developments in forthcoming new personal communications devices, according to Silicon Valley high tech company VSLI Technology Inc.

In an interview with Reuters, VSLI President and Chief Operating Officer Richard Beyer said smaller than ever chips will allow the information techology industry to provide a mind-boggling array of new products.

"The shrinking size of chips - with current technology able to cram tens of millions of transistors on to centimetre-square chips - reduces the size of personal communications devices to handheld and, in the near future, to lapel pin size," Beyer said.

Beyer said products in the future will allow finger nail-sized devices implanted in the ear, with radio communication, to instantly translate languages and allow normal conversation between people with no knowledge of each others' languages.
Tiny medical devices implanted in the body will allow instant diagnosis of problems like heart attacks and automatically offer mitigating treatment.

"In the last 20 years computing power which would take a whole room full of equipment, crammed with people and climate controlled, would be needed for tasks which can now be done with a lap-top computer. Soon these circuits will be able to be reduced to the size of an infant's finger nail," said Beyer.
"We will see an enormous increase in computing and communications power at exceptionally low prices with very low power requirements leading to easy portability."

"Twenty years ago, you only saw the cellphone in the hands of presidents or military leaders. They would be surrounded by aides and have the equipment packed on to a truck. Now it has been miniaturised to hand-held size. Soon it will be the size of a finger-nail."

VLSI is based in San Jose, California, and makes chips used in communications, digital entertainment, and to a declining degree, personal computers. Last year its sales totalled $717 million, and it made a net loss of $49.5 million after a charge of $116 million mainly due to the personal computer business.
For several years the company has been undergoing a transition out of the computer chip business and into more profitable areas like wireless communications and TV set-top boxes.
Beyer was in Brussels to address a Wall Street Journal Europe sponsored conference.

"If the last half of the 20th Century was dominated by a continuing revolution in computer technology, I'm convinced that the first half of the 21st century will witness a personal communications revolution with the development of low-cost, high performance intelligent integrated circuits," Beyer said.
*Personal communications devices linked by satellite which allow real time navigation.
*Wireless personal entertainment centres, combining satllite TV receiver, Internet browser and telephone.
*Electronic wallets connected to banks allowing access to bank account data and the loading of cash.
